title: Nuclear Charge Radii of Nickel Isotopes 58−68,70 Ni
speaker: 曹星灿
paperTitle: Nuclear Charge Radii of the Nickel Isotopes  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block">  <msup>    <mrow></mrow>    <mrow>      <mn>58</mn>      <mo>−</mo>      <mn>68</mn>      <mo>,</mo>      <mn>70</mn>    </mrow>  </msup>  <mtext>Ni</mtext></math
paperAbstract:
Collinear laser spectroscopy is performed on the nickel isotopes  
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block">  <msup>    <mrow></mrow>    <mrow>      <mn>58</mn>      <mo>−</mo>      <mn>68</mn>      <mo>,</mo>      <mn>70</mn>    </mrow>  </msup>  <mtext>Ni</mtext></math , using a time-resolved photon counting system. From the measured isotope shifts, nuclear charge radii <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>c</mi></msub></math> are extracted and compared to theoretical results. Three ab initio approaches all employ, among others, the chiral interaction <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block"><msub><mtext>NNLO</mtext><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></msub></math>, which allows an assessment of their accuracy. We find agreement with experiment in differential radii <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block"><mi>δ</mi><mo fence="false" stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>r</mi><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo fence="false" stretchy="false">⟩</mo></math> for all employed ab initio methods and interactions, while the absolute radii are consistent with data only for NNLOsat. Within nuclear density functional theory, the Skyrme functional SV-min matches experiment more closely than the Fayans functional <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block"><mtext>Fy</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>,</mo><mtext>HFB</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.
